div1.p: Wood has received oral permission from Blossom Reed to examine copies of Walter Reed's letters, which are in Hench's possession.

div1.head: Letter from Laura Wood to Philip Showalter Hench, March 26, 1942
div1.opener:
230 S. Philadelphia 19th St.
Philadelphia, Pa.
March 26, 1942
Dear Dr. Hench:
div1.p:
1st - I talked to Blossom this morning and asked her if she
would drop you a note saying it was all right with her if you
let me see her copy of Reed's letters. She said she was too
confused and busy to write a note, but I should write you my-
self, give you her love (she has quite a crush on you), say
Granny is sick still and that the cook has left and that she
is trying to feed the nurses and get organized to go to the
country and that it will be perfectly all right with her if
you let me see the copy of the letters that you have. I said
you were a punctilious fellow and would rather have it in her
own writing, but I couldn't press it very well, esp. as I
imagine she's rather rattled by the domestic problems of which
she spoke very feelingly. Do you suppose that that is explicit
enough permission? As you know, I want to see them principally
so that I can say I've had access to unpublished letters, and
positively do not want to quote them in any way.

2nd - Kelly tells, on page 10 of the 2nd edition, a story about
Reed and a Bklyn doctor who came to him when he was Health In-
spector to report the death of a child. He couldn't even de-
scribe symptoms properly, and when Reed said “It must have been
...,” mentioning a disease with a Latin name, the other
dr said, “Yes it must have been ...” and mispronounced the name.
My problem is, what could the disease have been: a children's
disease with a Latin name, prevalent in 1875, not too common or
even a bum doctor would have recognized it probably, and on the
other hand not too exotic. Gen Kean suggested status lymphati-
cus, but another dr when I mentioned it howled and said
status lymphaticus was almost a medical joke - something
to which poor drs attributed death when they couldn't figure
out the real cause. Can you think of a better one? Or should
I let it go at that? I'd rather not make a boner if I can help
it.

Now we are going to move Monday or Tuesday, and everything is
getting to look more disconsolate and depressing here by the
minute. So, when you find time to write me next, it had better
be at the Philadelphia address.

I'm glad you're looking forward with such zest to the illustra-
tions. I'm asking all my friends to buy the book but please
not read it. I don't mind if they look at the pictures, though.
